tags: I’ll stan them till the very end of all things
thank you so much for sending this in!
it spoke to me on a spiritual level
summary: The scene where Jon gives Arya Needle will forever be one of my favourite scenes, ever, and it’s what helped etch the both of...
question: The scene where Jon gives Arya Needle will forever be one of my favourite scenes, ever, and it’s what helped etch the both of them onto my heart. You could tell how much they love and care for each other and that’s the first reason I loved them. They were a comfort to each other when they were made to feel like they didn’t fully belong, and that spoke to me. (Also, you daily posting of Arya positivity is so heart warming, thank you for posting them!)
answer:
JON AND ARYA ARE MY LIFE

I love everything you’ve posted here omg stop my heart can’t possibly grow any bigger (by stop I mean pls continue I live for these two)

Yeaaasssss I’ve rewatched and read that moment a thousand times omg

Every time I think about how much they love each other, I cry. Like, they both grew up feeling so lonely and ostracized and they found solace in each other and that’s just??? So pure??? The greatest relationship to grace our pages?? They haven’t even seen each other in forever but they’re always thinking about the other and I’m emotional

I’m getting all the feels right now, oof, thank you love ❤️❤️

(And ahh you’re welcome! I’m just so grateful people are appreciating them, so thank you for telling me! :) Arya deserves so much better so I’m happy to do my part ❤️)

summary: We are due a third “secret wedding” in the show
title: We are due a third “secret wedding” in the show
body:
We had the first “secret wedding” (timeline wise)  between Rhaegar Targaryen and Lyanna Stark that tore apart the 7 Kingdoms…

and we had a second “secret wedding” between Robb Stark and Talisa Maegyr/Jeyne Westerling that brought death and destruction on House Stark and the North (aka the Red Wedding)

Since GRRM (and D&D) loves doing things in three…here’s hoping a third “secret wedding” between Jon and Sansa will unify the 7 Kingdoms, bring peace and prosperity and maybe for the first time have two Northerners rule Westeros.

Maybe we could see a “secret wedding” with Bran, Arya, Brienne, and Samwell as the witness, may be at the Winterfell godswood, before things Winterfell gets destroyed and then after they have taken the Iron Throne and delivered Westeros from the clutches of Daenerys and Cersei, another public wedding at King’s Landing/Dragonpit. This would parallel Jaehaerys and Alysanne’s two marriages as well.

blog.name: wolfprincessarya
blog.title: Arya of Winterfell
blog.description: sideblog dedicated to a little girl that is good & kind & brave & loyal. also the westerosi version of batman. maybe. we'll see.

tags: i didn't set out to make myself sob like a baby
this really got away from me
i just wanted to complain and declare my coping method of choice
i just needed to get it out of my chest
body:
of reunions and jaded hearts

so… let’s not kid ourselves. the bar is pretty low, but still, they’ll surely find a way to let us down. again. and with TWOW so far from the horizon, the stress is gonna kill me first.

but i am not gonna let it. no matter what happens on the show, Bran, Arya, and Jon’s reunion will be no less than perfect in my mind, and that’s final. it’s gonna fill our hearts till they burst, and fool us into getting our hopes up, against all better knowledge. it can even be kinda show-canon-compliant. mayhaps it even happens immediately after Sansa’s “Winterfell is yours, your grace”:

Jon had probably only just entered Winterfell, moments before Dany and her delegation did, with barely enough time to say hello and give a brief warning to the hastily-gathered welcome wagon of northeners, before assuming his king face for the introductions.

then there’s clamoring, the swift, repeated thunking of heavy wood against stone, and Arya wheels into the scene with Bran, at break-neck speed, all windswept and panting the both of them. they had obviously been hurrying to get there, and when Arya almost crashes them against a bannister the crisp winter air echoes with Bran’s startled giggles, beside himself. and then she almost crashes them again immediately after, as she abruptly halts, eyes wide.

 "Jon!“ she exclaims, joyful and earnest.

finally, our first glimpse of the real Arya. the one burried under all the pain and trauma of a tiny little girl who had to run and hide for her life for years, who witnessed her loved ones fall and innocents suffer and the gods fail her again and again.

next thing, they’re both running at each other, Arya shamelessly jumping up into his arms. her momentum twirls them around as they hold each other and laugh. when Jon finally gets his legs right under him he just stands there, all content, just stares up at her as she rests her forehead against his. their breaths mingle in visible clouds between their radiant smiles.

a polite cough brakes through their daze. Jon gently puts Arya down, almost reluctuntly. he tucks an erand strand of hair behind her ear and touches her cheek softly. ignoring the crowd about them as they awkwardly fidget, he then turns to his little brother.

"hello, Jon” Bran’s smile is sad, yet soft.

Jon covers the distance in two long strides.

–and, ok, Isaac is way too tall for this and Kit not enough, but in my head they’re not, and so:–

he sweeps Bran up too, and swings him around, and kisses his head, and hugs him close as all the heartache and pain and delight wash over him.

Bran hugs back twice as tight. he shuts his eyes and burries his face in the fur of Jon’s coat, and he lets himself be a boy that he had to forget how to be oh so long ago. he lets himself have this, just for a couple of heartbeats. maybe three. just three.

for three short heartbeats winterfell is not all covered in white. the wind still carries the scent of late summer in his memories, and Bran’s ears prickle with the noises of friendly sparring and baby Rickon’s high-pitched laughter. Robb and ser Rodrik are offering encouragements over the thunking of wooden swords, and their parents are just at the edge of his periphery, calmly seeing to the needs of those halcyon days.

He keeps his eyes closed for a heartbeat longer.

tags: Jon is the Prince of Dragonstone
the dragonglass was his from the beginning
and let's stop pretending that Dænerys was helping Jon because she is an amazing person
she helped because she needed him to be busy while she was starting her war against Cersei
title: The Prince of Dragonstone
body:
I was reading an interesting post that ended on my dashboard and I always found very interesting the fandom confusion about titles.

This post, for example, said:

the dragonglass she let them mine in HER ancestral home


Well, I’ll never call Jon Aegon BUT this statement is ridiculous because there is something deeply ironic about it since it’s based on the fact that Dænerys is the Princess of Dragonstone and therefore the dragonglass in that cave is hers… this fact was proved false by the revelation of Rhaegar and Lyanna secret wedding.

If you are part of the fandom that loves to think that Jon is a Targ*ryen now and that he will restore that dynasty because of this then this also means that Jon is the heir to the Iron Throne, not Dænerys.

Therefore Dragonstone doesn’t belong to Dænerys.

The last Prince of Dragonstone was Rhaegar because this title was traditionally used by the heir to the Iron Throne and Dragonstone belonged to the heir.

Following the events of Robert’s rebellion, Viserys became Prince of Dragonstone because he was the heir apparent and Dænerys after him because she was his heir.

BUT Rhaegar and Lyanna legal wedding established that Jon is Rhaegar’s heir, ergo, heir to the Iron Throne and rightful Prince of Dragonstone.

Can’t you see the irony of that statement now?

Jon asked for something that was already his and Dænerys gave him something that wasn’t hers to give.


Anyway, even if we don’t consider that Jon is the real Prince of Dragonstone and we decide to consider the characters POV how absurd it is that the other part of the fandom likes to highlight Dænerys good actions when they start talking about how she agreed to let Jon mine dragonglass?

She did it, I’m not saying she didn’t, but at that time dragonglass held no value for her so I don’t see how this action can be considered as something she did because she has a good heart.

On the contrary, it proves how little Dænerys considered Jon at that time.

Tyrion:Let him mine the Dragonglass.
If he’s wrong it’s worthless.  
You didn’t even know it was here. It’s nothing to you.  
Give him something by giving him nothing.  
Take a step toward a more productive relationship with a possible ally. Keep him occupied while we focus on the task at hand.  
Casterly Rock.

Letting Jon mine dragonglass is her way to keep him busy giving up something that means nothing for her.

Jon knows how precious dragonglass is ( more valuable to him now than gold) and the viewers know that Jon is right and dragonglass is extremely valuable to fight the NK BUT Dænerys doesn’t and, considering she didn’t want to help him unless he bends the knee, I’m not sure she would have given up dragonglass so easily if she believed how important it was for him.

So don’t bring up dragonglass as if Dænerys was doing something great for Jon.

She did, but that was not her original intention: her intention was to fool Jon while she was busy conquering Westeros.

summary: Jon is always protected by the Starks
title: Jon is always protected by the Starks
body:
His mother gave her life for him. 

[Gif from lovableamy]

Ned sacrificed his honor and lied to everyone, including his wife and his best friend, to keep Jon alive and raised him as his own son.

[Gif from  thenightkingcometh]

Bran warged Summer and saved Jon from the wildings when his undercover mission was blown up.

Sansa drove in with the Knights of Vale when Jon almost lost the Battle of Bastards.

Benjen sacrificed himself to save Jon from the wights. 

[Gif from lovableamy]

Even Cat, despite all the bitter feelings toward Jon, made a wooden circle to pray for his safety and sat with him throughout the night when he was down with the pox.

More to come in S8, I believe.

blog.name: northsky7
blog.title: Sansa Is Queen, Jon Is Political

summary:
Are Jon and Sansa plotting together?
Could it be possible that political Jon is part of a hidden plot orchestrated by Jon and...
body:
Are Jon and Sansa plotting together?

Could it be possible that political Jon is part of a hidden plot orchestrated by Jon and Sansa? I see this potentially being a major twist in the upcoming season.

As I understand it, the consensus is that Jon started playing the game on his own a while after he had arrived Dragonstone. I believe that the political Jon scheme was forged earlier in Winterfell by both Jon and Sansa working together. Earlier I wrote a post that goes more into depth on this, here (although my ideas have matured somewhat since writing it).

I am also seriously starting to believe that by the time Jon gets back to Winterfell, Sansa already knows about R+L=J and that she will use this knowledge to stay ahead of the game. But first, consider this:

A potential hidden scheming plot between Jon and Sansa

The issue that first triggered my tinfoil theory on the possibility of Jon and Sansa plotting together, was Sansa’s behavior before Jon left for Dragonstone. Up until then, she has learned from the best players in the game, utilizing these lessons in order to survive. Then the show led us to believe that she does the exact opposite, just letting Jon leave for Dragonstone knowing he doesn’t have a solid game plan or backup plans if everything turns to shit? Why would she take such a passive approach when Jon’s life, Winterfell and the North is at risk? If Jon fails his mission, this will no doubt put her own safety and future at risk. It makes no sense to me. Especially when she knows how reckless he can be. Jon’s plan to fight Ramsay in BotB despite having fewer men proved to her that Jon is a massive risk taker. Jon went ahead with the battle knowing his chances of winning were slim. And that is why Sansa mobilized the army of the Vale; because she knew he needed her help to win. With that in mind, taking into account her journey and struggles, I believe there is no way that she would let him go without sharing her political knowledge with him and strategizing with him, thereby strengthening his chances of success. By working together and trusting each other (foreshadowed in S6), they could have developed a solid game plan and contingency plans that would ensure (his survival and) a successful mission. 

Just to clarify, I believe Sansa was blind-sighted by Jon’s decision to leave when he announced this at the meeting with the NL. However, I think there was an important off-screen conversation between the two of them after that meeting or perhaps the night before he left. And even though I think Jon can play the game on his own, I suspect that political Jon might be part of an overall joint strategy planned by them both.

The show tells us that Sansa and Jon are innocent, honorable and naïve with a strong moral code (much like their father/uncle). On the other hand, their actions show us a different, darker side to them. Both Sansa and Jon have played the game in order to survive, although seemingly with their moral compass intact. But now, as KitN and Lady of Winterfell, they both know the stakes are much higher. They are undoubtedly players in the big game now, a game where you win or die. I believe the letters they received from both Cersei and Daenerys made that clear to them beyond a doubt. And they need each other to make it through this. I think that was the point D&D was trying to get across when Jon and Sansa were butting heads. After the BotB I also think Jon saw that they can be stronger when working together as a pack, instead of him acting on his own as a lone wolf. And Tyrion’s comment to Jon, that Sansa is a lot smarter than she lets on, could be foreshadowing Sansa’s role in Jon’s game.

In terms of them plotting and strategizing, I believe their journeys so far have taught them that in order to survive they must play the game, and they must play it better than their opponents. And the only way to do that is to think and act like their enemies, skills that I believe both Jon and Sansa have mastered (exemplified by Jon vs the Wildlings and Sansa vs Littlefinger). So why would it be any different when Jon goes to Dragonstone when the stakes are even higher? The only logical answer in my mind is that when Jon goes south he goes well prepared for potential scenarios in his meeting with Daenerys, with Sansa’s support and guidance – and that he is prepared to do whatever it takes to protect their family and their people, no matter the cost to their pride or honor.

So what is the game plan?

Hypothetically, say that Jon and Sansa are plotting together, what would their game plan be? Based on Jon’s skills as a military man/strategist and Sansa’s skills as a politician, I could imagine it being something like this…

Phase 1: present the dire facts of the situation (the army of the dead is coming for us all), reason with Daenerys and appeal her to make the honorable choice; urge her to put her plans of conquering Westeros on hold to help save the world. In other words, use the Stark utilitarian approach where the best course of action is that which benefits the greater good. Meanwhile as a contingency plan (keeping the political game in mind), gather intelligence to learn what you can about your opponent (strengths and weaknesses), in case a change of tactics becomes necessary.

Phase 2: initiated once it is clear that Daenerys will not see reason. At this point use all means necessary to achieve a successful mission - the ends justifying the means. In other words, play the Machiavellian game that Sansa has learned from her «mentors». The ends being: keep Jon alive when dealing with the Dragon Queen, protect House Stark, Winterfell and the North, and hopefully save the people of Westeros from extinction. The means being: using manipulation, playing on Daenerys’ weaknesses – whatever it takes to get her on-board and invested in the fight against the dead in the North. This is where political Jon comes into effect. As Jon discovers that Daenerys’ weakness is, in fact, her infatuation with him, he uses this to his advantage by sleeping with her and submitting to her - getting her emotionally invested. 

Working and plotting together would certainly give Jon and Sansa a strategic advantage in the game, enabling them to be one step ahead of their opponents. I believe Sansa is a crucial player in this regard. While Jon plays the game in Dragonstone, on-screen Sansa prepares Winterfell for the Great War. Off-screen Sansa, on the other hand, could be lobbying the NL, secretly building alliances and strengthening Jon and Sansa’s position for when the Dragon Queen arrives Winterfell. While “fighting every battle in her mind” and considering “every possible series of events happening all at once”, she could be preparing for various scenarios that could arise once Daenerys arrives Winterfell. She could be making strategic plans on how to handle potentially dangerous situations with Daenerys. And if the assumptions by @thelawyerthatwaspromised are correct, that Jon and Sansa have been in communication more than once during his time in Dragonstone (I can’t find the actual post, sorry), intelligence and insider information from Jon on Camp Dany would help Sansa in this effort.

So how would R+L=J play a part in this? Here is where it gets really interesting. After reading this post by @fortunatelylori, it dawned on me. What if Bran has told Sansa who Jon really is? That would certainly change the rules of the game for Sansa, especially considering:

  1. She knows that she is the Key to the North. 
  2. She knows that Daenerys wants the North.
  3. She knows Tyrion is coming to the North and that Daenerys might possibly demand that their marriage is consummated, thereby gaining control of Winterfell and the northernmost Kingdom through Tyrion. 
  4. She knows that at some point Camp Dany will find out about political Jon.
  5. She knows that once it is revealed that Jon is the rightful heir to the Iron Throne, Daenerys will most likely change her status from friend to enemy. 

Although I cannot speculate on the details of Sansa’s strategies in Winterfell just yet, I do think @fortunatelylori is definitely on to something in regards to Tyrion. In her post, she argued that Jon and Sansa could secretly marry to prevent Sansa from having to meet Daenerys’ demands of reinstating her marriage to Tyrion. I definitely think the marriage issue will come up considering marriage is a key part of her narrative. But I also believe there is a possibility that Jon and Sansa could secretly marry before Daenerys even raises the issue, as a result of Sansa’s beforehand knowledge of R+L=J. 

So basically my theory rests on the assumption that Jon and Sansa trust each other and are strategizing together, Jon relying heavily on Sansa’s help and support; which he will most certainly need when he comes back to Winterfell. In S8, I believe much of her arc will be about utilizing all the lessons she has learned, enabling her with the capability to calculate the moves of her opponents and adjusting the Starks’ moves accordingly, therefore being one step ahead of the game. A skill I think she has mastered after having been “mentored” by the best schemers in the game. The irony perhaps being that the schemers, who sought out to abuse and manipulate Sansa, are outsmarted by their victim as a result of them unknowingly passing on the rules and tactics of the game on to her. And I think this could be one of the biggest twists in the show, considering her character development, going from a naive stupid girl (which she herself has claimed to be on several occasions) to becoming a mastermind player in the Game of Thrones.    

I know my tinfoil theory has flaws and holes that have yet to be explored, but I hope it makes some kind of sense.

In other words, play the Machiavellian game that Sansa has learned from her «mentors». The ends being: keep Jon alive when dealing with the Dragon Queen, protect House Stark, Winterfell and the North, and hopefully save the people of Westeros from extinction. The means being: using manipulation, playing on Daenerys’ weaknesses – whatever it takes to get her on-board and invested in the fight against the dead in the North. This is where political Jon comes into effect. As Jon discovers that Daenerys’ weakness is, in fact, her infatuation with him, he uses this to his advantage by sleeping with her and submitting to her - getting her emotionally invested. 

Working and plotting together would certainly give Jon and Sansa a strategic advantage in the game, enabling them to be one step ahead of their opponents. I believe Sansa is a crucial player in this regard. While Jon plays the game in Dragonstone, on-screen Sansa prepares Winterfell for the Great War. Off-screen Sansa, on the other hand, could be lobbying the NL, secretly building alliances and strengthening Jon and Sansa’s position for when the Dragon Queen arrives Winterfell. While “fighting every battle in her mind” and considering “every possible series of events happening all at once”, she could be preparing for various scenarios that could arise once Daenerys arrives Winterfell. She could be making strategic plans on how to handle potentially dangerous situations with Daenerys. And if the assumptions by @thelawyerthatwaspromised are correct, that Jon and Sansa have been in communication more than once during his time in Dragonstone (I can’t find the actual post, sorry), intelligence and insider information from Jon on Camp Dany would help Sansa in this effort.

So how would R+L=J play a part in this? Here is where it gets really interesting. After reading this post by @fortunatelylori, it dawned on me. What if Bran has told Sansa who Jon really is? That would certainly change the rules of the game for Sansa, especially considering:

  1. She knows that she is the Key to the North. 
  2. She knows that Daenerys wants the North.
  3. She knows Tyrion is coming to the North and that Daenerys might possibly demand that their marriage is consummated, thereby gaining control of Winterfell and the northernmost Kingdom through Tyrion. 
  4. She knows that at some point Camp Dany will find out about political Jon.
  5. She knows that once it is revealed that Jon is the rightful heir to the Iron Throne, Daenerys will most likely change her status from friend to enemy. 

Although I cannot speculate on the details of Sansa’s strategies in Winterfell just yet, I do think @fortunatelylori is definitely on to something in regards to Tyrion. In her post, she argued that Jon and Sansa could secretly marry to prevent Sansa from having to meet Daenerys’ demands of reinstating her marriage to Tyrion. I definitely think the marriage issue will come up considering marriage is a key part of her narrative. But I also believe there is a possibility that Jon and Sansa could secretly marry before Daenerys even raises the issue, as a result of Sansa’s beforehand knowledge of R+L=J. 

So basically my theory rests on the assumption that Jon and Sansa trust each other and are strategizing together, Jon relying heavily on Sansa’s help and support; which he will most certainly need when he comes back to Winterfell. In S8, I believe much of her arc will be about utilizing all the lessons she has learned, enabling her with the capability to calculate the moves of her opponents and adjusting the Starks’ moves accordingly, therefore being one step ahead of the game. A skill I think she has mastered after having been “mentored” by the best schemers in the game. The irony perhaps being that the schemers, who sought out to abuse and manipulate Sansa, are outsmarted by their victim as a result of them unknowingly passing on the rules and tactics of the game on to her. And I think this could be one of the biggest twists in the show, considering her character development, going from a naive stupid girl (which she herself has claimed to be on several occasions) to becoming a mastermind player in the Game of Thrones.    

I know my tinfoil theory has flaws and holes that have yet to be explored, but I hope it makes some kind of sense.

Are Jon and Sansa plotting together?

Could it be possible that political Jon is part of a hidden plot orchestrated by Jon and Sansa? I see this potentially being a major twist in the upcoming season.

As I understand it, the consensus is that Jon started playing the game on his own a while after he had arrived Dragonstone. I believe that the political Jon scheme was forged earlier in Winterfell by both Jon and Sansa working together. Earlier I wrote a post that goes more into depth on this, here (although my ideas have matured somewhat since writing it).

I am also seriously starting to believe that by the time Jon gets back to Winterfell, Sansa already knows about R+L=J and that she will use this knowledge to stay ahead of the game. But first, consider this:

A potential hidden scheming plot between Jon and Sansa

The issue that first triggered my tinfoil theory on the possibility of Jon and Sansa plotting together, was Sansa’s behavior before Jon left for Dragonstone. Up until then, she has learned from the best players in the game, utilizing these lessons in order to survive. Then the show led us to believe that she does the exact opposite, just letting Jon leave for Dragonstone knowing he doesn’t have a solid game plan or backup plans if everything turns to shit? Why would she take such a passive approach when Jon’s life, Winterfell and the North is at risk? If Jon fails his mission, this will no doubt put her own safety and future at risk. It makes no sense to me. Especially when she knows how reckless he can be. Jon’s plan to fight Ramsay in BotB despite having fewer men proved to her that Jon is a massive risk taker. Jon went ahead with the battle knowing his chances of winning were slim. And that is why Sansa mobilized the army of the Vale; because she knew he needed her help to win. With that in mind, taking into account her journey and struggles, I believe there is no way that she would let him go without sharing her political knowledge with him and strategizing with him, thereby strengthening his chances of success. By working together and trusting each other (foreshadowed in S6), they could have developed a solid game plan and contingency plans that would ensure (his survival and) a successful mission. 

Just to clarify, I believe Sansa was blind-sighted by Jon’s decision to leave when he announced this at the meeting with the NL. However, I think there was an important off-screen conversation between the two of them after that meeting or perhaps the night before he left. And even though I think Jon can play the game on his own, I suspect that political Jon might be part of an overall joint strategy planned by them both.

The show tells us that Sansa and Jon are innocent, honorable and naïve with a strong moral code (much like their father/uncle). On the other hand, their actions show us a different, darker side to them. Both Sansa and Jon have played the game in order to survive, although seemingly with their moral compass intact. But now, as KitN and Lady of Winterfell, they both know the stakes are much higher. They are undoubtedly players in the big game now, a game where you win or die. I believe the letters they received from both Cersei and Daenerys made that clear to them beyond a doubt. And they need each other to make it through this. I think that was the point D&D was trying to get across when Jon and Sansa were butting heads. After the BotB I also think Jon saw that they can be stronger when working together as a pack, instead of him acting on his own as a lone wolf. And Tyrion’s comment to Jon, that Sansa is a lot smarter than she lets on, could be foreshadowing Sansa’s role in Jon’s game.

In terms of them plotting and strategizing, I believe their journeys so far have taught them that in order to survive they must play the game, and they must play it better than their opponents. And the only way to do that is to think and act like their enemies, skills that I believe both Jon and Sansa have mastered (exemplified by Jon vs the Wildlings and Sansa vs Littlefinger). So why would it be any different when Jon goes to Dragonstone when the stakes are even higher? The only logical answer in my mind is that when Jon goes south he goes well prepared for potential scenarios in his meeting with Daenerys, with Sansa’s support and guidance – and that he is prepared to do whatever it takes to protect their family and their people, no matter the cost to their pride or honor.

So what is the game plan?

Hypothetically, say that Jon and Sansa are plotting together, what would their game plan be? Based on Jon’s skills as a military man/strategist and Sansa’s skills as a politician, I could imagine it being something like this…

Phase 1: present the dire facts of the situation (the army of the dead is coming for us all), reason with Daenerys and appeal her to make the honorable choice; urge her to put her plans of conquering Westeros on hold to help save the world. In other words, use the Stark utilitarian approach where the best course of action is that which benefits the greater good. Meanwhile as a contingency plan (keeping the political game in mind), gather intelligence to learn what you can about your opponent (strengths and weaknesses), in case a change of tactics becomes necessary.

Phase 2: initiated once it is clear that Daenerys will not see reason. At this point use all means necessary to achieve a successful mission - the ends justifying the means. In other words, play the Machiavellian game that Sansa has learned from her «mentors». The ends being: keep Jon alive when dealing with the Dragon Queen, protect House Stark, Winterfell and the North, and hopefully save the people of Westeros from extinction. The means being: using manipulation, playing on Daenerys’ weaknesses – whatever it takes to get her on-board and invested in the fight against the dead in the North. This is where political Jon comes into effect. As Jon discovers that Daenerys’ weakness is, in fact, her infatuation with him, he uses this to his advantage by sleeping with her and submitting to her - getting her emotionally invested. 

Working and plotting together would certainly give Jon and Sansa a strategic advantage in the game, enabling them to be one step ahead of their opponents. I believe Sansa is a crucial player in this regard. While Jon plays the game in Dragonstone, on-screen Sansa prepares Winterfell for the Great War. Off-screen Sansa, on the other hand, could be lobbying the NL, secretly building alliances and strengthening Jon and Sansa’s position for when the Dragon Queen arrives Winterfell. While “fighting every battle in her mind” and considering “every possible series of events happening all at once”, she could be preparing for various scenarios that could arise once Daenerys arrives Winterfell. She could be making strategic plans on how to handle potentially dangerous situations with Daenerys. And if the assumptions by @thelawyerthatwaspromised are correct, that Jon and Sansa have been in communication more than once during his time in Dragonstone (I can’t find the actual post, sorry), intelligence and insider information from Jon on Camp Dany would help Sansa in this effort.

So how would R+L=J play a part in this? Here is where it gets really interesting. After reading this post by @fortunatelylori, it dawned on me. What if Bran has told Sansa who Jon really is? That would certainly change the rules of the game for Sansa, especially considering:

  1. She knows that she is the Key to the North. 
  2. She knows that Daenerys wants the North.
  3. She knows Tyrion is coming to the North and that Daenerys might possibly demand that their marriage is consummated, thereby gaining control of Winterfell and the northernmost Kingdom through Tyrion. 
  4. She knows that at some point Camp Dany will find out about political Jon.
  5. She knows that once it is revealed that Jon is the rightful heir to the Iron Throne, Daenerys will most likely change her status from friend to enemy. 

Although I cannot speculate on the details of Sansa’s strategies in Winterfell just yet, I do think @fortunatelylori is definitely on to something in regards to Tyrion. In her post, she argued that Jon and Sansa could secretly marry to prevent Sansa from having to meet Daenerys’ demands of reinstating her marriage to Tyrion. I definitely think the marriage issue will come up considering marriage is a key part of her narrative. But I also believe there is a possibility that Jon and Sansa could secretly marry before Daenerys even raises the issue, as a result of Sansa’s beforehand knowledge of R+L=J. 

So basically my theory rests on the assumption that Jon and Sansa trust each other and are strategizing together, Jon relying heavily on Sansa’s help and support; which he will most certainly need when he comes back to Winterfell. In S8, I believe much of her arc will be about utilizing all the lessons she has learned, enabling her with the capability to calculate the moves of her opponents and adjusting the Starks’ moves accordingly, therefore being one step ahead of the game. summary: Isn’t it beautiful that when Arya and Jon felt like outsiders, like they didn’t belong they found a safe have in each other?...
body:
Isn’t it beautiful that when Arya and Jon felt like outsiders, like they didn’t belong they found a safe have in each other? Now, they are all grown up and have finally found their place on the world I want to see them supporting each other once they reunite.

Their bond is so strong and beautiful.

tags: a song of ice and fire
title: The Lion’s Pride Pt. Three
body:
Summary: You finally reached your final destination across the narrow sea



Jorah’s hand had wrapped around your arm tightly and pulled you down behind a rock as well as Tyrion. And you went down with an audible thud.

“A slave ship.” Jorah pointed out to an empty space of water near by. No doubt there was a ship there, but how could he tell it was a slave ship.

“Why are the anchored?” You asked looking to the older man.

His eyes were watching the ship intently as it just floated there in the water like all ships do.

“They probably came ashore for—“

You heard a sword scraping against the metal lips of it’s sheath as it was drawn “Water.” A man finished in a deep voice. His accent was thick and heavy, one you’d never heard before. You grabbed onto your dress, almost subconsciously trying to pull it closer to yourself.

Turning your head you saw a group of five men holding their sword like weapons. To short to be a sword. To long to be a dagger.

You stood along with Jorah and looked at them. You’d never seen people like them before. So much cloth and utilities around their waist attached to their belt. If you didn’t know any better, you’d say they were pirates. Well… Slavers and Pirates were… similar in some ways.

They’d taken you to the shore, where their boats sat that would take them back to the ship. You sat on your knees next to Tyrion and Jorah. In a line of sorts.



“Got a lot of fight in you, huh?”

You let out a angered huff as the captor hit Jorah once more. This trip was turning more and more into an adventure. You needed a nap, you needed to actually see and verify your daughter was alright.

Jorah fell to the ground and the captor who assumed was also the captain of the ship turned to walk a little ways away.

“Salt mines?” He asked one of his men, standing by his side eyeing Jorah and then looking to your Uncle and to you before looking back at Jorah.

“Yeah, that or a galley slave.” He confirmed “He looks strong enough.”

The captor then looked to your uncle again and an unimpressed look crossed his face. Most people looked down upon dwarfs. Though, you never understood why. Tyrion was a very clever man.

“Worthless.” His comrade spoke. Your brows furrowed at his decision but you didn’t argue. You didn’t want to take any chances with him. He could decide to cut your tongue out if he found you to be too mouthy

“Cut his throat.”

“Wait! Wait! Wait! Wait! Wait!” Tyrion repeated in a panic his hands going up defensively as you subconsciously positioned yourself to bolt up and attack if you needed to. You hadn’t realized you’d done it until one of the slavers came over and shoved you down onto the dirt.

“Let’s discuss this!” Tyrion continued

“And then chop off his cock. We’ll sell it for a fortune. A Edward’s cock has magic powers” He stated.

What was it with these people. Did people east of Westerns just have a fascination with dwarfs?

The captor began to walk away to the boats, and the man he had been talking to took out his weapon and walked towards Tyrion

“Wait! Wait! Wait! You can’t just hand a dry cock to a merchant and expect him to pay for it!”

You had been pushed over next to Jorah back on your knees to be back in the original position you’d been in. The man had brought his weapon to Tyrion’s neck but seemed to be waiting for his commander’s orders.

“He has to know it came from a dwarf! And how could he know unless he sees the dwarf?”

Tyrion’s head had been turned back to the man who’s dagger was against his throat. The man using the sword to make him look back at him.

“It will be a dwarf-sized cock.” He responded

“Guess again.”

Ew. Tyrion looked the man dead in the eye while you made a face. The slaver looked to the commander waiting for what he had to say. You could hear the sound of a canteen being plugged up again from behind you right before he spoke

“The dwarf lives until we find a cock merchant.”

Tyrion let out an audible sigh of relief, that for the millionth time in his life has spared it.

“What of the girl?” The man asked walking over to you and lifting your chin with the dagger to look at him. You glared at him and let a huff out through your nose.

“Whore house?” He questioned

“No. She’s had children. She’ll go with the man.” He stated

You turned your head to look at the commander as he eyed you up and down. “How would you know that?”

“How old are you?” He asked

You didn’t want to answer. But you knew you had to

“Eighteen. Almost nineteen.”

“No eighteen year old has the hips of a mother, unless they are a mother.” You shrugged slightly and made an impressed face. He wasn’t wrong. Before you’d had Lucia your hips where slender, and maybe because of how small you were when you had her, only being 15 when you had fallen pregnant and 16 when you gave birth, your hips had widened noticeably.

One of the men picked you up by your upper arms and took you to one of the paddle boats pushing you to step into it. Carefully you stepped in and sat down messing with the extra length of rope around your wrists

“Queen Daenerys has outlawed slavery.” Jorah said almost like a demand

“We’re bound for Volantis, not Slaver’s Bay. Besides, reopened the fighting pits. I’ve never heard of free men fighting in the pits.” The commander responded

“I have.” You interupted.

He looked at you and rose a brow at what you’d said. You’d only seen a fight in a pit once. And it wasn’t pretty

“It was a trial.” You responded. He only rolled his eyes and looked back at your uncle and Jorah

“The fighting pits in Meereen? You’re in luck, then! You’re about to be rich! You are looking at one of the great warriors in the seven kingdoms.” Tyrion said. Jorah. Her Jorah Mormont of Bear Island. During this whole debacle you’d forgotten that Jorah had once been a talented fighter.

“Him? He’s got to be sixty years old.” He responded

“Sure, he’s a bit long in the tooth, a bit withered, been in the sun too long.”

You gave Tyrion a look, of all the things he could say he was choosing that? He was just confirming that fact that Jorah was an older man.

“We can all see that. But he is a veteran of 100 battles. They wrote songs about him!”

The commander put his foot up on the bow of the boat and gestured for his men to bring Jorah closer

“That true?”

Jorah just looked like he was struggling to nod before he was able to and once again Tyrion began to wiggle you all out of your deaths.

“He won the tournament at Lannisport. Unseating Ser Jaime Lannister himself.”

The commander began laughing at Tyrion putting his foot down and standing up straight and Tyrion face dropped while you and Jorah looked on at the interaction you never thought you’d see.

“The Kingslayer!”

“Jousting. You’re talking about jousting A fancy game for fancy lads. The men who fight in the pits of Merreen will swallow him whole.”

“I killed a Dothraki bloodrider in single combat.”

You looked to Jorah amazed. Cause if it was true, he had to be the best. The Dothraki were some of the fiercest fighters anyone’s ever seen.

The commander got off of the boat you were sitting in and walked over to Jorah and stood less than a foot away from his face.

“Liar.”

“It’s no lie. His name was Qotho. He was bloodrider to Khal Drogo. Take me to Slaver’s Bay, put a sword in my hand, I’ll prove my worth.”



“This one’s a Westerosi knight”

You closed your eyes as the chains put a weight on your wrists and your neck. Some men from Meereen standing in front in a small crowd, as the commander and Jorah stood on a pathetic looking wooden stage. The last time you saw a stage someone was killed.

“He’s from an ancient house trained in sword and lance. He fought beside the stag King Robert  on the far side of the Narrow Sea. Betrayed by his woman he sold himself into slavery to repay his debts. Biding begins at 12 gold honors.”

The small crowd began murmuring as you and Tyrion stood side by side watching as the men in bright blue, green and white discussed it to themselves

“Twenty” One man offered taking out a bag of coins and throwing it to the commander who swiftly caught it and began pulling Jorah to the the man who you assumed was his new ‘master’”

The man began to take Jorah away, dragging him by the chains he was attached to.

“Wait! You have to buy us as well!” Tyrion yelled trying to run forward, the man behind you both grabbing onto his chain and yanking him back as best he could.

“Why?” The buyer asked shrugging his shoulders.

“We’re all a team. She’s a great fighter too.” Tyrion said pointing to you.

Your eyes went wide as you glared at the top of his head your hands balling into fists. The crowd laughed. Yes, because how would a woman know how to fight?

“He’s funny. You have to give him that” The commander said with a smile after he was done laughing himself.

Tyrion looked at you as the man kept trying to pull Tyrion’s chain. And you decided to prove his point. With your quick movements you turned and grabbed Tyrion’s chain yanking the man forward so hard he fell to the ground with a loud thud, you and Tyrion both began to hit him. Small plates of armor placed closely together and surrounded by leather to make it into a vest of sorts. You’d put your hair up with a ribbon they’d given you. Your golden hair coming down in waves, something Tyrion said looked like a waterfall as it was put in the ponytail.

You wore chainmail on your arms and had your sword sharpened by Jorah. Of course you’d never been taught how to sharpen your own sword. But you held the golden hilt, thumb on the large jewel that sat on the rain-guard of the sword.

This sword would be used in battle today. A sword that had never seen it. Not once. And at a point in time it used to be part of a larger sword which saw many battles during Robert’s Rebellion. A large sword that had been held by Ned Stark. And then once split into two, held by Joffrey Baratheon and Jaime Lannister. Then Joffrey died. And Jaime gave his sword to Brienne of Tarth. And Varys told the sword out of Joffrey’s crypt for you.

You could hear the fighting of the first few who had gone out. The sound of steel hitting steel and the sound of men grunting as they were killed by their opponents.

You were snapped out of your thoughts when Jorah came running back from the entrance. He didn’t speak a word, but he grabbed his sword and helmet. And you being how you were, grabbed your own as Tyrion asked what you were doing.

But you followed him. And when he opened the door to the fighting pits you followed him out. You could see the blood in the sand and the dead men laying on the ground in a pool of their own blood.

The man who had bought you three tried to stop you, grabbing unto the back of Jorah’s vest, but you kept going. Walking towards the fight. You didn’t want to die and you’d been damned if you never saw your little girl because you died in a fighting pit.

What was it Arya had said? About what she said to the god of death every day?

Not Today.

You would remember that everyday. Every time you walked through he staircase you and Arya had made your escape from. The very staircase where she pointed her sword at you defensively. She was younger than you, and you had learned from her.

You had a grip on your sword as you went in helmet securely on your head as you went up to a man who was beating in the skull of another with a rock. With the flat of your sword you knocked him out, the amount of force creating an open wound on the side of his bald head.

She had long silver hair that was done up in an extravagant style, something you’d never seen in King’s Landing.

Daenerys Targaryen.

Jorah removed his helmet to reveal to her his face to her. You left yours on. She wouldn’t recognize you. All she’d see was a small golden haired girl who was shorter than herself. A small golden haired girl who apparently had the hips of a mother.

Daenerys’s face softened as she looked at him, and then once again harden. Just as fast as it had softened

“Get him out of my sight.”

Jorah looked like he was about to start begging her. And he did. His head held high as looked up to her

“Khaleesi, please. I just need a moment of your time.”

Two guards grabbed onto Jorah’s arms and they pushed you aside as if you were another object. In the way

“I brought you a gift!” Jorah yelled out as the guards where taking him away.

“It’s true!”

Tyrion had walked out, the chains that had attached him to the wall… Still attached to his wrists, but not to the wall. Someone had broken him free from staying by the wall.

The mother of dragons looked over to see the dwarf Lannister walking behind Jorah and next to you.

“He has.” You finished

“And who are you” She asked her dark brows furrowing in confusion, anger and frustration.

“We are the gift.” Tyrion responded holding up his chains for her to see. She still looked confused as she looked from your uncle to you and back and forth in a cycle.

“It’s a pleasure to meet you, Your Grace.” You greeted with a warm smile. And a nod.

“My name is Y/N Baratheon, he is Tyrion Lannister”

This sword would be used in battle today. A sword that had never seen it. Not once. And at a point in time it used to be part of a larger sword which saw many battles during Robert’s Rebellion. A large sword that had been held by Ned Stark. And then once split into two, held by Joffrey Baratheon and Jaime Lannister. Then Joffrey died. And Jaime gave his sword to Brienne of Tarth. And Varys told the sword out of Joffrey’s crypt for you.

The man who had bought you three tried to stop you, grabbing unto the back of Jorah’s vest, but you kept going. Walking towards the fight. You didn’t want to die and you’d been damned if you never saw your little girl because you died in a fighting pit.

Not Today.

You would remember that everyday. Every time you walked through he staircase you and Arya had made your escape from. The very staircase where she pointed her sword at you defensively. She was younger than you, and you had learned from her.

You had a grip on your sword as you went in helmet securely on your head as you went up to a man who was beating in the skull of another with a rock. With the flat of your sword you knocked him out, the amount of force creating an open wound on the side of his bald head.

Grabbing the back of one of the men’s vests, you pulled him back and pulled his arm over your should with so much force you could hear the sound of his shoulder dislocating and his forearm breaking in half.

You could feel the blood start to run down your cheek, but the adrenaline had stifled the pain of the large, deep cut. You turned and again with the flat of your sword hit him upside the head knocking him clean out

You looked at Jorah as walked forward to the platform for a woman stood. Her dress was a smooth white fabric, a cape around her shoulders and showing off a nice medal chest piece which was attached to her cape. It was in the shape of two dragon wings, and three dragon heads protruding from the center. She had long silver hair that was done up in an extravagant style, something you’d never seen in King’s Landing.

Daenerys Targaryen.

You slowly approached her, only a few feet behind Jorah as the unsullied by her side held up their spears and got closer with their shields up closer.

Jorah removed his helmet to reveal to her his face to her. You left yours on. She wouldn’t recognize you. All she’d see was a small golden haired girl who was shorter than herself. A small golden haired girl who apparently had the hips of a mother.

Daenerys’s face softened as she looked at him, and then once again harden. Just as fast as it had softened

“Get him out of my sight.”

Jorah looked like he was about to start begging her. And he did. His head held high as looked up to her

“Khaleesi, please. I just need a moment of your time.”

Two guards grabbed onto Jorah’s arms and they pushed you aside as if you were another object. In the way

“I brought you a gift!” Jorah yelled out as the guards where taking him away.

“It’s true!”

Tyrion had walked out, the chains that had attached him to the wall… Still attached to his wrists, but not to the wall. Someone had broken him free from staying by the wall.

The mother of dragons looked over to see the dwarf Lannister walking behind Jorah and next to you.

“He has.” You finished

“And who are you” She asked her dark brows furrowing in confusion, anger and frustration.

“We are the gift.” Tyrion responded holding up his chains for her to see. She still looked confused as she looked from your uncle to you and back and forth in a cycle.

“It’s a pleasure to meet you, Your Grace.” You greeted with a warm smile. And a nod.

“My name is Y/N Baratheon, he is Tyrion Lannister”
